newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Judicial reform to be part of Argentine IMF deal.
newsitem.headline: Judicial reform to be part of Argentine IMF deal.

text.p: Argentina is planning a far-reaching reform of its judiciary as part of a deal for a new Extended Fund Facility from the International Monetary Fund, La Nacion newspaper reported Monday.
The World Bank is backing the measures, and will give an initial $50 million credit to the country to modernize its courts, La Nacion said, citing government officials.

"An adequate modernization of the courts, which includes a rigorous information system, will also help improve tax income," Alberto Abad, secretary of strategic planning in the Cabinet, told La Nacion.
The reforms would be aimed at improving the reliability of the legal system to investors, reducing legal costs and increasing the transparency of the legal system.
A mission from the World Bank arrived in Argentina last week to meet with officials from the legal system.

Argentina's current stand-by accord with the IMF, which ends this year, includes a fiscal deficit target of $3 billion for 1997. Argentina met the first quarter target with a deficit of $1.04 billion.
The country is currently negotiating a three-year EFF to kick in when the stand-by agreement ends.
Economy Minister Roque Fernandez recently said that Argentina will need no more loans from the IMF after the new EFF ends in 2000.
"This will be the last EFF agreement with the IMF. This ends in 2000. We should all expect this to be the last agreement with the IMF," Fernandez said.
